Main Page   Modules   Data Structures   File List   Data Fields  

Class String container.

Functions used by the ANSI C kernel functions, Last updated 1/27/2000. More...

Data Structures

struct  TString
 A container for a string, includes corresponding functions to manipulate the string. More...


Defines

#define k_AddFileAndLine(str)   {char* i=(char*)malloc(sizeof(char)*25);k_AddCharToString('(',&str);k_AddCharArrayToString(__FILE__,&str);sprintf(i," line %d",__LINE__);k_AddCharArrayToString(i,&str);k_AddCharToString(')',&str);free(i);};
 This macro (define-macro) appends complete path/file information and line number in source code from where this function is called.


Functions

void k_InitString (TString *pString)
 Sets the pointer pChars in TString to NULL.

void k_EmptyString (TString *pString)
 Deletes all allocated memory for the string and sets variables to 0.

void k_DeleteString (TString *pString)
 Deletes all text containe in the string and and leaves a '\0' charcter only.

void k_AllocString (TString *pString, unsigned int InitialSize)
 Allocates memory for the array of characters in the TString structure.

void k_ReAllocString (TString *pString, unsigned int NewSize)
 Reallocates memory for the TString structure.

void k_AdjustSizeOfString (TString *pString)
 Removes unused memory allocated for characters in the TString structure.

void k_AddCharToString (char Character, TString *pString)
 The given character is added to the string.

void k_AddCharArrayToString (const char *pCharArray, TString *pString)
 The given array of characters is added to the string.

void k_SprintfString (TString *pString, char *fmt,...)
 Works like the normal ANSI C funktion sprintf except the result is store in a TString structure.

bool k_InsertCharInString (char Character, unsigned int Index, TString *pString)
 Insert the given character at given Index, which must be less than the NumberOfChars (stored in the TString structure).

bool k_RemoveCharFromString (unsigned int Index, TString *pString)
 Removes a character stored in the string at given index, the order of the characters is preserved.

void k_CopyString (TString *pDest, const TString *pSource)
 Copies whole group from "pSource" to "pDest".

char * k_FindInString (const char *pStr, const TString *pSource)
 Search for given string pStr in the string list.

void k_StringToUpper (char *str)
 Converts the entire character array contained in str to upper case characters.

void k_ConvertCharacters (char *str, char SearchChar, char ReplaceChar)
 Searches the given string "str" for the character in "SearchChar" and replaces them with the character in "ReplaceChar".

Detailed Description

Functions used by the ANSI C kernel functions, Last updated 1/27/2000.

Since string handling is very limited in ANSI C it was necessary to write these helper functions. Works on a TString structure. These functions are part of the Image Processing Library IPL98.

Version:
1.10
Author:
René Dencker Eriksen (edr@mip.sdu.dk)

Define Documentation

#define k_AddFileAndLine (  str    )     {char* i=(char*)malloc(sizeof(char)*25);k_AddCharToString('(',&str);k_AddCharArrayToString(__FILE__,&str);sprintf(i," line %d",__LINE__);k_AddCharArrayToString(i,&str);k_AddCharToString(')',&str);free(i);};
 

This macro (define-macro) appends complete path/file information and line number in source code from where this function is called.

Used to produce error/warning messages. To remove path/file information comment out the call "k_AddCharArrayToString(__FILE__,&str)" and to remove line information comment out the call "k_AddCharArrayToString(i,&str)". This functions is found in the file kernel_string.h".

Parameters:
str  (TString) String to append the path/file and line number to.

Function Documentation

void k_AddCharArrayToString (  const char *    pCharArray,
TString *    pString
) 
 

The given array of characters is added to the string.

The function keeps track of allocation and updates the AllocatedChars member in TString.

Parameters:
CharArray  (char*) Array of characters to append to string.

void k_AdjustSizeOfString (  TString *    pString ) 
 

Removes unused memory allocated for characters in the TString structure.

Because memory allocation is a time consuming operation it is a good idea by each k_ReAllocString() (or k_AllocString()) call to allocate a big number of characters and then at the end of the construction of a TString calling this k_AdjustSizeOfString function to deallocate unused memory.

Definition at line 89 of file kernel_string.c.

References TString::AllocatedChars, TString::NumberOfChars, and TString::pChars.

void k_AllocString (  TString *    pString,
unsigned int    InitialSize
) 
 

Allocates memory for the array of characters in the TString structure.

To make appendings fast, call this funcion with a value in InitialSize greater than the expected characters in the string.

Parameters:
InitialSize  (unsigned int) Number of characters to allocate memory for. Must be 1 or greater.

Definition at line 58 of file kernel_string.c.

References TString::AllocatedChars, k_EmptyString(), TString::NumberOfChars, and TString::pChars.

void k_ConvertCharacters (  char *    str,
char    SearchChar,
char    ReplaceChar
) 
 

Searches the given string "str" for the character in "SearchChar" and replaces them with the character in "ReplaceChar".

Parameters:
str  Pointer to an array of characters.
SearchChar  Character to be replaced.
ReplaceChar  Replace with this character.

void k_CopyString (  TString *    pDest,
const TString *    pSource
) 
 

Copies whole group from "pSource" to "pDest".

Previous data in "pDest" are destroyed.

void k_DeleteString (  TString *    pString ) 
 

Deletes all text containe in the string and and leaves a '\0' charcter only.

That means one character is left in the string so that printing the string will not fail.

Definition at line 51 of file kernel_string.c.

References k_InitString(), and TString::pChars.

Referenced by k_CharArrayToListText(), and k_FindText().

void k_EmptyString (  TString *    pString ) 
 

Deletes all allocated memory for the string and sets variables to 0.

Always call this function when leaving a scope where a TString variable were created and used.

const TString *    pSource
) 
 

Search for given string pStr in the string list.

Parameters:
pStr  String to search for.
Returns :
If found a pointer to the beginning of the found position in pSource is returned, else returns NULL.

void k_InitString (  TString *    pString ) 
 

Sets the pointer pChars in TString to NULL.

Initialises all integer to 0. Always call this function when creating a variable of the TString type

bool k_InsertCharInString (  char    Character,
unsigned int    Index,
TString *    pString
) 
 

Insert the given character at given Index, which must be less than the NumberOfChars (stored in the TString structure).

The ordering of the character is preserved.

Parameters:
Character  (char) Character to append to string.
Returns :
False, if Index is out of range.

Definition at line 162 of file kernel_string.c.

References k_AddCharToString(), k_AddFileAndLine, k_EmptyString(), k_InitString(), k_ShowMessage(), TString::NumberOfChars, and TString::pChars.

void k_ReAllocString (  TString *    pString,
unsigned int    NewSize
) 
 

Reallocates memory for the TString structure.

The new allocated memory is not initialised.

Parameters:
NewSize  (unsigned int) The new number of characters to allocate memory for. Note: The NewSize may be less than the actual allocated memory! In that case the corresponding characters stored in the end of the actual memory are deleted.

bool k_RemoveCharFromString (  unsigned int    Index,
TString *    pString
) 
 

Removes a character stored in the string at given index, the order of the characters is preserved.

Parameters:
Index  Index of character in the string to be removed.
Returns :
False, if Index is out of range.

void k_SprintfString (  TString *    pString,
char *    fmt,
...   
) 
 

Works like the normal ANSI C funktion sprintf except the result is store in a TString structure.

Parameters:
fmt  (char*) Control format string exactly as the one given to "sprintf" in C. Must be followed by the corresponding arguments as in a "sprintf"-specification.
